tool.name: Trim.flows
tool.description: partition by barcode, trim to length, cull by length and mismatches
tool.command:
echo 'trim.flows( flow=$flow, minflows=$minflows, maxflows=$maxflows, #if $maxhomop: maxhomop=$maxhomop, #end if order=$order, signal=$signal, noise=$noise, #if $oligo.add == "yes": oligos=$oligo.oligos, bdiffs=$oligo.bdiffs, pdiffs=$oligo.pdiffs, tdiffs=$oligo.tdiffs, ldiffs=$oligo.ldiffs, sdiffs=$oligo.sdiffs, #end if fasta=$fasta, processors='\${GALAXY_SLOTS:-8}' )' | sed 's/ //g' ## mothur trips over whitespace | mothur &&
## move output files to correct destination prefix="$flow" && mv \${prefix%.dat}.trim.flow "$trim_flow" && mv \${prefix%.dat}.scrap.flow "$scrap_flow" && mv \${prefix%.dat}.flow.files "$flow_files" && #if $fasta: mv \${prefix%.dat}.flow.fasta "$flow_fasta" && #end if #if $oligo.add == "yes": mv \${prefix%.dat}.*.flow . && #end if mv mothur.*.logfile "$logfile"

param.name: flow
param.label: flow - flowgram data
param.help: Use sffinfo to generate flow data from an sff file

param.name: add
param.label: Trim with an oligos file?
param.help: a file that can contain the sequences of the forward and reverse primers and barcodes and their sample identifier. Each line of the oligos file can start with the key words "forward", "reverse", and "barcode" or it can start with a "#" to tell mothur to ignore that line of the oligos file

param.name: bdiffs
param.label: bdiffs - number of differences to allow in the barcode (default 0)

param.name: pdiffs
param.label: pdiffs - number of differences to allow in the primer (default 0)

param.name: tdiffs
param.label: tdiffs - total number of differences to allow in primer and barcode (default 0)

param.name: ldiffs
param.label: ldiffs - total number of differences to allow in linker sequence (default 0)

param.name: sdiffs
param.label: sdiffs - total number of differences to allow in spacer sequence (default 0)

param.name: minflows
param.label: minflows - Minimum number of flows that each sequence must contain to make it in to a "trim" file. (default 450)

param.name: maxflows
param.label: maxflows - Maximum number of flows after which all other flows should be ignored (default 450)
param.help: (Quince uses 360 for GSFLX and 720 for Titanium)

param.name: signal
param.label: signal - treat any intensity signal greater than this threshold as a real signal

param.name: noise
param.label: noise - treat any intensity signal less than this threshold as noise

param.name: order
param.label: order - flow order for nucleotides in the sequencer
param.help: default is A, was TACG. Also accepts B or I

param.name: fasta
param.label: fasta - translate the flowgram data to fasta sequence format

tool.help:
@MOTHUR_OVERVIEW@
**Command Documenation**
The trim.flows_ command is analogous to the trim.seqs command, except that it uses the flowgram data that comes bundled in the sff file that is generated by 454 sequencing. It's primary usage is as a preliminary step to running shhh.seqs. Chris Quince has a series of perl scripts that fulfill a similar role [1]. This command will allow you to partition your flowgram data by sample based on the barcode, trim the flows to a specified length range, and cull sequences that are too short or have too many mismatches to barcodes and primers.
.. _trim.flows: http://www.mothur.org/wiki/Trim.flows
